title: Sydney revealed as cocaine capital of Australia - but ice remains the most used drug in the country
text:
Drug testing of a number of sewage plants has revealed Sydney is the cocaine capital of the country but ice was still the most used drug nationally.

Drug testing of 52 sewage plants across Australia found cocaine consumption is higher in New South Wales than anywhere else, most notably within Sydney.

The Australian Criminal Intelligence Commission found Australia's cocaine use remained highest in NSW, with some parts of Queensland and Victoria also testing highly.

Drug testing of a number of sewage plants across Australia found Sydney is the cocaine capital of the country while ice was still the most used drug nationally (stock image)

'Australians have an insatiable demand for all sorts of narcotics and synthetic drugs,' the commission's chief executive Michael Phelan told reporters in Brisbane.

'That demand has not gotten any better.'

Results from sewage testing carried out in February and April showed a drop in fentanyl and oxycodone, but an increase in methamphetamine, cocaine, heroin and MDMA.

Levels of nicotine and alcohol have remained relatively steady.

The testing has no way of determining drug use by suburb and includes waste from private residences, prisons, hospitals, offices, hotels and shopping centres.

It also cannot distinguish between prescribed or illicit opioids use, or whether nicotine intake is from tobacco, e-cigarettes, patches or gum.

Drug testing of 52 sewage plants across Australia found cocaine consumption is highest in Sydney and wider New South Wales than the rest of Australia (file photo)

Results from the testing showed a drop in fentanyl and oxycodone, but an increase in methamphetamine, cocaine, heroin and MDMA

'It's not a perfect science, but it's better than nothing,' Mr Phelan added.

Mr Phelan told the Brisbane Times there was tonnes of ice being used in the country.

'We know there has always been a demand, but what (the figures) show is actually how much is demanded by the Australia community,' Mr Phelan said.

'For example, when we look at the figures we can show that when it comes to ice, we've been able to show there's almost 10 tonnes being used by the Australian community across the board.'

The ACIC said the testing represented half of the nation's population and the results will be used to inform government policy and decision making, as well as policing operations by providing the locations of tested sewage facilities.

The report comes just one week after the same testing revealed Adelaide had the highest concentration of meth use in the country.

A more recent study of wastewater in Queensland found the drug fentanyl was present in the water system in country Queensland sparking fears Australia could be heading towards an opioid crisis.

Meanwhile the Northern Territory had the highest concentration of capital city of ice use and Victoria had the highest capital city concentration of heroin.

authors: Adam Mccleery For Daily Mail Australia
